resources:
Sanz Mikva 001 Language/שפה Help cancel help READY Need More Time done Thank You! Remove make-up and skin lotions. Remove nail polish. Cut, file and clean finger and toe nails. Brush teeth; no particles of food should remain between teeth. Use dental floss (unwaxed preferred), only if you are sure it will not get caught between teeth. Rinse mouth with water. Bathe with warm water. Wash entire body thoroughly. Use soap and washcloth or loofah sponge Give careful attention to the following: corner of eyes, eyebrows, eyelashes, ears and earring holes, nose, under chin, underarms, elbows, back, around and under breasts, navel, genital area (also internally), between thighs, knees, between toes, soles of feet. Smooth hard skin and calluses. Soften and remove dry scabs provided bleeding will not occur. Remove protruding splinters. Wash hair with shampoo, without conditioners. Shower or rinse thoroughly with a non-moisturizing soap or body wash. Comb all hair while still wet. It is helpful to place a towel under the hair so loose hair will not fall on body. If preparations are made at home, shower and recomb your hair at the mikvah. Check your body, visually and by touching, using a mirror when needed to ensure that you are free of intervening substances. Remove contact lenses or eyeglasses. Use the bathroom if necessary, be sure to wash all areas to ensure clean of toilet tissue, etc and re comb pubic hair.
Remember to do Seventh day bedika before Shkiah. Preparations should be done calmly and slowly. Preferably main preparations e.g. shampooing the hair and combing it out, should start whilst still day continuing until nightfall, and then immerse in the Mikvah. If that’s not possible, at least a significant part e.g. teeth and nails should be done whilst daytime. If preparations start only after nightfall, a full hour should be spent doing them. Those who prepared at home, must rewash, comb and recheck themselves at the Mikvah. All jewellery and earrings must be removed. The Halacha obligates to wash in hot, comfortable water, whilst the Minhag obligates that this be done in a bath tub. Scabs should be softened in warm water. Consult a Rav on the following prior to preparations: Stitches in any part of the body, temporary fillings, hair growth between laser hair removal treatments, burns wounds or a cast.
Brush teeth thoroughly, clean between teeth with a tooth pick or dental floss and rinse well [those with fixed braces, clean fixtures well False teeth or removable braces have to be removed. Extra care has to be taken to remove all makeup, especially from lips and within skin creases. Remove all eye discharge, remnants of makeup and loose eyelashes from the corners of the eye. It’s recommended to go over the outside of eyes with a wet Q-tip to ensure that there is no residues of eye makeup. Remove contact lenses. Clean the inside and outside of the nose with a wet finger. Clean the face with soap and warm water. Clean behind the ears and in the folds and the inside with a Q-tip. Remove earrings and clean the hole; one can use the earring stick to do so. Shampoo the head with hot but comfortable water and rinse well, then comb out well. In cases of dandruff, comb out with a fine toothed comb whilst shampoo is on the hair, but don’t scrape the scalp. In case of lice or nits, one should comb out with a lice comb and remove as much as she can as much as she would do at home. Consult with the Mikvah attendant.
Those who remove the hair of the head, should do so before immersing, and preferably three days before. Cut nails and toenails well and make sure there aren’t any sharp edges remaining. Clean well around the nails and underneath them. Check well that there is no remaining colour or nail varnish, especially in the corners. Remove hanging loose skin from around the nails. Clean the hand well especially in crevices. Clean armpits and hair well removing traces of dry sweat or deodorant. Use a comb. Wash the neck, back of the neck, shoulders and back, well. Wash breast area, underneath the breast and nipples removing dry milk. Remove dirt and dry sweat from the body folds and clean the navel well. A Q-tip is helpful for navel. Wash well between the legs and private parts with soap and warm water and then comb out the hair. Insert a finger slightly in the vaginal opening and clean with warm water. The anus should be cleaned well with soap and warm water. Those who have a Nuvaring with permission of their Rav, should remove it before immersing.Legs Wash well the thighs, knees, ankles and sole. Remove and wash all dirt between toes. Hard skin should be softened in warm water. A pumice stone could be used. After completing preparation, one must inspect the entire body and head to insure that in is completely clean. Rinse again the entire body with warm water but without soap. Comb out thoroughly the hair of the head, armpits and genital area. [On Shabbos one should wet the hair with the warm Mikvah water and then separate the hair gently with one’s fingers to make sure there are no knots. Inspect all places possible and use a mirror for the face. Places which are not possible to see should be inspected by feel of the hand. Remove any foreign body, e.g dentures, retainer, contact lenses, nuvaring. If something was eaten after cleaning the teeth, clean them a second time as above. Use the bathroom if needed and then clean the area again. General things which need to be removed: Body dirt, dry sweat, dry blood, dry milk, loose skin, paint, makeup, glue, plaster, remaining glue from plaster, unwanted body hair, wax, uncut nails.
Any uncertainty or question, one should ask the Mikvah attendant – they are there to help. Any Halachic question should be asked a Rav prior to immersion and not suffice with asking afterwards.
Some have the Minhag to wet the hidden parts of the body with the Mikvah water prior to immersion. These places include: between the toes, the intimate folds, the navel, stomach folds, under and between the breasts, armpits, behind the ears, eyelids, lips, and between fingers. During immersion care has to be taken not to seal the eyes or lips tightly, only gently and passively. The immersion posture should be, slightly bent forward, legs slightly apart, arms slightly away from the body. After the first immersion the Bracha is recited. During the Bracha one should cross the arms below the heart without touching covered parts and look away from the water. Some have the practice to cover the head during the Bracha. The Bracha: \n "ברוך אתה ד' אלוקינו מלך העולם אשר קדשנו במצוותיו וצונו על הטבילה". The Minhag is to immerse another twice after the Bracha in the same way as the first. Others have the Minhag to do more. After immersion the Minhag is to approach or touch the Mikvah attendant, in order not to meet firstly with something impure. One is not allowed to wash themselves after immersion whilst in the Mikvah building. Some have the custom to eat something before leaving the Mikvah building. Some also rub their nails on a rough surface after immersion. When arriving home, one should say verbally to the husband, “I have immersed” or “I am pure”.
